title: As all say in my position, help would be greatly appreciated
content:
And one more time, help would be greatly appreciated. In fact, if anyone lives in the nort central texas area, I’ll buy you a drink for some help. I have spent days trying to find this font. I’ve found ones very close, but the “e” and the “r” are always off.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081205033957im_/http:/typophile.com/files/logo_4337.JPG)

 [‹ Fantomas Type](http://web.archive.org/web/20081205033957/http:/typophile.com/node/49643 "Go to previous forum topic") [Hotel Stationary Font? ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081205033957/http:/typophile.com/node/49674 "Go to next forum topic")
author: camwel

comments.content: It appears that that ’e’ fell off the truck, got hit by a few cars, pushed to the shoulder where it then sat for a few weeks shriveling in the sun, before some kind soul finally picked it up and gave it a home in the middle of that logo.

What do you want to do / need doing with this - recreate it or improve on it? It could badly do with an overhaul in my opinion.

JH

I would guess it is avant garde with a (poorly) modified e and r. Plus a [squooshed](http://web.archive.org/web/20081205033957/http:/typophile.com/node/12967) n in _Weldon_ and an attempt at a unicase T in _contractors._

To the aboves: For now, I really want to find the name of the font. Overhauls are in order, but might have to come further down the line.

To Cumaso: thanks for the help. So this is not a basic font? It’s a modified font?

It is possible that there’s a font that matches this, but I doubt it.

My guess is that it has been modified. It is common practice for designers to modify a few letters of a font when designing logos. When this is done well it makes the logo more distinctive, when it’s done poorly it looks like garbage.

If you need to recreate this logo I would try converting Avant Garde to outlines in Illustrator then modifying the e, r, n, and T to match.
